div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette THE reve DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTAGLIGHED 1880. | Ritter and Manager - - R SHELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIEP.
div.p: TUESDAY, JANUARY’ 7, 1908.
THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.

The strategic importance of the Hedjaz rail- way in regard to Egypt: is very great and we advise.all interested in this great undertaking to peruse the series of three instructive articles from the Cairo Correspondent of “The Times” on the progress made in the construvtion of the railway from Damascas td Mecca.
“The Times” in a leading article on. the subject points out that when it is. completed and connected with the Anatolian Railway by

means of the existing system in Sytia and the ‘continuationiof the Baghdad ‘line’ as -far as Aleppo, it will be, a strategical factor of the first importance. By means of it the Turkish troops from Constantinople, Asia Minor, and Syria can be transported in a few days into the Arabian peninsula or concentratéed with even greater ease on the frontiers of Egypt without having to, make any part of the journey by sea, an important point for the Sultan, who a fleet but no navy. ‘By means of it the Sultan will be able to tighten his grip on the unruly Arab tribes who from time to time. have given him and his predecessors no small ‘amount of trouble, and he will be able with much greater effect than at,present to threaten our position on the banks of thé -Nile, should he ever be 20 ill-advised as to wish to do so. Even as it is, unfinshed and unconnécted with the Anatolian line, it has been found useful for the transport of troops to fight the rebels in Yemen and tor strengthening the influcace of the Constantinople Government bver the Beduin tribes. » Another advantage which the Sultan will derive from bridging the distance between the seat of his government and the Holy Cities of Islam is that it will enable him to keép a closer watch over the local magnates of Mecca aud: Medina, whose influence over their fellow-citizens aud whose. tendency to _ regard themselves as semi-independent are. 80 little to“his liking that he generally retains some members of their families a$ hostages in Constantinople.

The importance which ‘Abdal Hamid at- taches to these objects may. /be ‘measured by the extent to which in the construction of this railway he has .broken through all the old traditions and violated ali the precedents’ of Ottoman administration. The history of the undertaking is striking proof that, if pro- phecy is always dangerous, it is doubly danger- ous in dealing with Turkish affairs. Thé cons- truction of the. Hedjaz Railwayhas not been an easy task. Everything needéd for the line has had to be imported from abroad, some of the eouatry through which it passes presents considerable technical. difficultities, and great- est obstacle of all, over long stretches of the line there is no. water to be “found. No one, and especially no. one acquainted, with the corruption and inefficiency which are the chief characteristics of Turkislt administration, believed that a Palace Commission would suc- veed’ in laying, as it has already done, 600 miles or more’ of. well-constructed . railway running” forthe greater part of its length through sand and stone deserts, and is ac- complishing that task at a rate and at a cost which make the line compare very favourably in those respects with similar railways cons- tructed ‘under :‘European management. Still less was it believed that the management of ° the enterprise would be marked by the absolute honesty to which our Correspondent testifies in common with other competent observers ; and it did not tend to lessen this scepticism that the responsible control of the work was placed in the hands of the man who is believed to have first suggested the idea of biilding the railway, the Sultan’s: Second Secretary ahd Chamberlain, the Syrian Izzet Pasha. Much of the credit for the success which has been achieved is undoubtedly due to Meissner Pasha, the. German engineer in charge of the actudlswork of construction, to whom our Correspondent pays a warm tribute. His. energy and techilical skill, his .knowledge and sympathy with. the .Turkish character, and his power of inspiring his subordi- nates with his own enthusiasw have obviously ‘been important factors in the progress 6f-the undertaking. The flattering reception he receiv- ed both from the Sultan and from Izzet’Pasha ‘ _on ‘the occasion of his recent visit to Constan- tivople, and still more the comparatively free hand he enjoys in his own department, are -}-sufficient proof that his services are appreciated at Yildiz. “He would, however, be the first to acknowledge that he would have been unable to do what he has done had he not been loyally supported by his employers.

It is perhaps even yet too early to. say for certain that the high standards which have hitherto been observed will be maintained to the erid. Moreover, as the railway approaches the Holy ‘Gities the Bedouin tribés, who, if not positively friendly, have so far done little or nothing to interfere with the work, may be- cotne alarmed at the menace to their, vested “| interests. The tribes around Mecca and Me- dina depend for their livelihood on hiring camels to the pilgrims, and many. of the magnates in the Holy Cities are interested in the traffic, ‘That local feelings of this kind can- not be lightly disregarded is shown by the , trouble which is now being made by people who have property at Jeddah and whose in- dignation was aroused by the decision to choose Rabigh instead of Jiddah as the Red Sea port of the railway. None thé less, we may “| take i¢ as almost certain that the*work wil! be completed, even if not quite so speedily as is now -expected. ‘Unfortunately, the dis- organization which is already to be noticed in the traffic department makes it only too likely thatthe line, when finished, will not be managed in a way t0 fulfil the expectations of the Musul mans who have so liberally: contributed towards: the cost of building it. The Sultan and Izzet Pasha are evidently mach more anxious to construct the line than to ‘see it used in a business-like fashion. We can only hope that these apprehensions will not be justified. We-canhot ‘disguise from ourselves that the railway may some day be used to threaten our position in Egypt, and that efforts have béen made to give an anti- British bias to the Pan-Islamic policy which it is means to’ further, but we cannot regard without sympathy an enterprise in which our Musulman fellow-subjects ‘take auch a keen interest, and which, when, completed, will render it easier for them to fulfil their religious duty by making the pilgrimage to Mecca at : least once in their lives,

div.head: EGYPTIAN KOEPENIC . CASE-
div.p: Our Santa correspondent serlds us an account of how a'native of tHat district imposed opon the omdeh of Gimmaza. An Egyptian Kepenick, he writes: in the ‘ person of one Ahmed Saleh Mustapha, presented himself recently +0 the omdéh, of Gimmaza as engineer in charge of the Zifta bridge. He ordered the omdéh to provide him with ten men for work ongthe bridge and to collect a fax of P.T.-100 from each man: On leaving the yillage he went to the Santa ate and telephoned to the omdeh ‘asserting himself to'be the mamour, and as such gave instructions that the omdeh shonld give every assistance ‘to the engineer. On his return Alftued Sala fouod ‘everything, including the money, ready for him, and the same day left’Tantah.. He has been sentenced to one year’s imprisonment with-hard labour

div.head: KHARTOUM BRIDGE.
div.p: We have heard the question often asked remarks the “Sudan Times”, whether the Su- dan Government lias abandoned altogether she construction of a bridge connecting Khartoum with Omdirman, We have not received any of- ficial information on the subject,bat we under- stand thatthe construction of this bridge has ngtdfeen given up, though it is temporarily postponed owing to paucity of funds, and to the utilization of such funds as are available for the execution of projects of immediate ur- gency to the Government. When this bridge is taken in hand, we understand that it will not be a-railway bridge, but will be merely for foot and vehicle traffic. Ita costis figured at about LE..100,000.
Such a bridge will no doubt be. very benefi- | %4 cial to both the towns that it connects, and will considerably enhance the value of building land in bothstowns.

div.head: ARMS IN EGYPT.
div.p: One of thé principal causes of criminality in Egypt, writes a correspondent, is thé large quantity of arms which are to be found in the interior. The Government, in fact, seized] during the past yéar 40,000 arms (guns, rifles, and revolvers). A circular from the Ministry of the Interior ordering all gunsmiths to deliver up ‘in the course of this month all guns, rifles, and®revolvers under penalty of confiscation and the infliction of a fine.

div.head: FERTILISERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The organ of the Bnglish fruit trade,. “The Frait Grower,” remarks :-—

A trade which has been ‘increasing by leaps and bounds in Egypt during the past three or four years, and which will undoubtedly con- tinue to do so\for som@time to come; is that of artificial fertilisers. Statistics have -been prepared which show that in 1902 the total imports were 2,000 metric tons, valued at I.E. 18,000, whilst in 1906 tlie’ figures were nearly’ 13.000 motric tons, valued at over LE: 122,000. For the first nine months of 1907, the deliveries amounted | g to 7,579 metric tons, valued at LE. 76,907. Of | ¢ these imports-in 1906 the United’ Kingdom supplied:‘only 1,811 metric tons against Bel- gium’s 8,068 tons and America 2.798 tons P 1:Yet Egypt is, in'a way, supposed to be. under British control in return for, her expenditure of blood and treasure

Practically the only manures actually manu- factued in +Bgypt are those turned out by a , | Cairo company, such ‘as: ‘poudrette” and other ; | sewage products. The company also work up various slanghter-house products, such as dried ‘blood, powdered hoof and hom and ground bones. , When these were first put on the market some years ago, the company had ‘great difficulty’in selling theta, as thegnative . | did not appreciate the value of artificial manu- 3 | res. Chemical’ manures are allowed into the ‘| country. duty free, and ‘special reduced rates are in force on the State Railways for carriage into:the interior. There is no monopoly for the import of artificial fertilisers into Egypt, and any manufacturer or merchant is able to engage inthe trade,

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
div.p: “LOHENGRIN.”

Wagner performances sre, one would say, rather out of place in Cairo : the “elect and select” come in late, and leave early, and look rather bored, the rank and file applaud when- ever there is a convenient break in the music. Happily “Lohengrin” is fairly continuous, -but the few opportunities it offers were enthusias- tically seized. I fear that Herr Mottl, had he been conducting, would have led the orchestra to a personal assault on the audience, he cer- tainly would not have tolerated the casual and ill-tuned entrances of late-comers, or the noise and shuffling before the end of each act. Still the andience as a whole seemed to take: the performance of “Lohengrin” as a delicate com- pliment to their taste and powers of apprecia-| J tion, and the applause, though given at inex- cusable moments, during the acta !, was merited.

Far the best part of the whole performance was the singing of Mmes Magne and Fierens in thesecond act. Mme Magne was far less constrained than usual: she had - evidently studied the spirit of the music, and unquestion- ably both in voice and in treatment she revealed it to the full: the middle and more subdued tones of her voice were especially charming, and her bigh notes were pure, faultless and full of ‘feeling. And Mme Fier- ens! what a splendid Ortrud! her acting was the last word of realism, and her singing that of a real artiste who knew the music and the meaning of the part past all question. Her gestures, eyes, and voice —and what a fine voice! — expressed every detail and depth of power, passion, hate, cunning and evil triumph.

For the rest, M. Valette.was quite good as Tebramund, and M: Wiglio adequate as Henry the Fowler, but they—and this may be said of the chorus also—were hardly in touch with the misic.: it,was not convincing to them : but M. Valette has the makings of a really fine Tebra- mund, his sudden appearance from within the church was perhaps his best moment, he rose. to the situation. M. Soubeyran was yery far’ from convincing ; his voice has not the requisite power or résonance, and he takes the music in a species of cadence quite remote from its real movement: his farewell to the Swan was perhaps the only approach to.a success, but.it was too-affected. The orchestra was quite good, especially in the characteristic violin passages which constitute the real ‘motif’ of the work : but they also inclined to cadences now and. again ; andthe wedding chorus was harried ; it might have been a species of dance, taken as it was. Still the performance as a whole was far better than one might have expected, and the singing of Mmes Magne and Fierens would have been worth hearing anywhere.

div.head: NILE VALLEY C0.
div.p: Messrs. Lake and Currie, the company’s f engineers, report for, the month of November as follows :—Development—Winze CS. 2 has been sunk a further distance of 32 ft. 6 ins, making ‘the total depth 52 ft. 6 ins below C levék:Over the distance sunk during the month the reef carries an average value of 4.3 dwts, across an average width of 38.6 ins. If the ric sample, however, at 80 ft. be included, theh average value is increased to 84.dwts The improvement mentioned in our last report was, unfortunately, not maintained,- the samples taken in the bottom of the winze showing poor results. A drivesouth from winzeC § 2 has been started towards No. 1 shaft, and at the end of the month had advanced 7 ft. The reef mea- || sures 28 ina, but the assay results are not yet ‘to hand. Some fine piécéx of specimen stone, amounting to about 15 Iba in all, were |. | obtained from stope C N 1, at a point aboat 12 | ft north of winze BN 1. and in the line of a known “chute ot good ore. Milling—The 10 stamp mill treated 1,160 tons of ore, which . | yielded 293.47 ozs of fine gold, exclusive-of 1} ton of concentrates having an assay value of 36 dwts per ton. .

div.head: RIPLE SHOOTING.
div.p: The Khedive having expressed a wish to | give @ prize at the forthcoming Army and Navy Rifle meeting has decided to award the “Lloyd Lindsay”.

div.head: BIG UNIT SHIELD.
div.p: The first match in the “Big Units Shield” will be played at the Slade Ground, Abbassia, to-morrow between the Coldstream Guards and | - 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, commencing at 2.45 p.m. The Coldstreamers should manage to get into the second round without much difficulty if the Dragoons cannot improve on Saturday’s |, display. Sergt. Cussuck, RE, has been ap- pointed referee.

div.head: PERSONAL, AND--SOOIAL.
div.p: The Duke and Dacheds of Madrid are leaving Naples on the 10th inst. and should _ arrive in Alexandria about the 14th inst. They . will spend a day. at that port before coming ‘on _ to,Cairo where appartments have been reserv- ed for them at the Semiramis Hotel. After a short visit in Cairo they will in all probability — some time in-Upper Egypt.
Sir Eldon Gorst arrived at Port Sudan early yesterday morning with the Sirdar and left the same day for Suakim Sir Eidon intends payinga visit to Erkoweit.
Amongst those at- present staying at Ghezireh Palace are the Prince and Princess Gortchakoff, Laura Lady Grant, Colonel Ge- orge Cumberland ‘and Mrs, Hunting Howell who was so well known last season.

Lord and Lady Sefton are going to follow the example of several peers and peeresses, They are off on’s hunting expedition to Upper. Egyptand East Africa. Croxteth Hall, Liverpool, will be closed during their absence, and there. will be no parties there either forthe Waterloo ~ Cup week ‘or for the: Liverpool. Spring Races. - Lord and Lady Sefton's young family consists :. of two: sons,aged nine and eight,and a daughter, aged five. Lord Sefton joined Sir Henry Camp- bell-Bannerman’s Ministry /as Master of the Horse in succession to the Duke of Portland; but resigned that post a short time ago, as he - was not in agreement with the potioy_ of the Government.

Lord Sandwich has left England; for Bgypt. Hinchingbrooke, his4ordship’s seat, where he. gave agurden-party last July, lies between the town of Huntingdon and the yillage of Bramp- ton, whereSamuel Pepys often went to visit his father. Lord Sandwich, who is in his sixty-ninth year and a, bachelor, ‘is eighth in descent from Sir Edward Montagu, who, as Joint High Admiral of England, was instrumental in winning over. the navy t the,Restofation: of Charles II. He was created Karl of Sandwich; and twelve years later fell in the great sea-fight'with the Dutch at Southwold Bay. The family mottois: “Post tot nanfragia poream
Baron von Oppenhein, of the German Dipl matic Agency, at Cairo, arrived from Europe yesterday by the North German Lloyd steamer.
Count and Countess Hungadi-Laszlo and | Courit Leyden arrived yeaterday at Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.

Sir Donald abd Lady Currie are leaving Eng- land shortly for a long yachting cruise in the Mediterranean, when they will in all .proba- bility pay a visit. to: Egypt. Tt is probable that Viscount and Viscountess iy ces will ‘a0- company them.

It was announced a few days ago by a Cairo newspaper that Mirza Ashgar Khan, Persian Consul-Genefal in Egypt, bad been transferred in the same capacity to Constan- tinople. We learn from a thoroughly reliable source that this news is devoid of. all founda- tion.

Many AnglojEgyptians will welcome Sir John Maxwell when he visits Egypt with the Duke of Connangit shortly. The appointment of Major-General Sir John , Grenfell, Maxwell, K. C. B., who goes. dut, to Malta with the Duke, was an indicated selection; he had already serv- ed as Chief of Staff tothe Inspector-General, having been Chief Staff Officer, Third Army Corps, for'the last five:years. Further, he was at Tel-el-Kebir with the Ist Battalion Black Watch, and that action was the Dake’s baptism of fire: Later, he was on Grenfell’s staff ; and, later still, commanded the Fourteenth Brigade in South Africa, finishing up with the military governorship of Pretoria. After that, he mar: ried the daughter of so influential and desirable a father-in-law as Mr. C. W. Bonynge.

Captain Mark Sykes,-only son of Sir Tatton | Sykes. and brother-in-law of Sir Eldon Gorst, has applied tor a ‘commission in the new Territorial. Army. The Captain saw active | | service in the Boer war, and recently resigned his commission after spending ten years and a ° half in the old Constitutional Force. Captain Cecil Robinson, the new Director General of the Ports and Lights Administra- 4 tion, is expected to arrive at Alexandria by the Egyptian Mail Liné:steamer “Heliopolis.”
"We regret to report the sudden-death on’ Friday at her home in America of Mrs. Pickering the mother of Mrs. C.S. Spong and ; | ‘aunt of Mrs, Crookshank Pasha.
Kaimakam Grant Bey, Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, and Cobble Bey, Assis- tant Commandant of the -Alerandria City Police, have exchanged functions.

Mr.- Jobe Langley; Inspector General of Irrigation, Upper Egypt, has left Cairo on a tour of inspection. in Upper Egypt. ‘He is accompanied by Mra. Langley and they. will probably be absent for several weeks.
The celebrated Belgian violinist, M. Matsuk, arrived) at,’ Alexandria to-day: from Marbeilles and intends to giye some concerts at Alex; andria and Cairo.

div.head: SIR ELDON :GORST.
div.p: The text of Sir Eldon Gorst’s speech: at Khartoum came to hand~this. morning with the Sadan Mail. The speech. was made by Sir Eldon on landing, in response to a speech of welcome made by Sir Reginald Wingate/Pasha, who spoke ds follows :—

We, the: Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan ; the Officers, Non-Cotimissioned | ¢ Officers and’.men of, the British and Egyptian fordes ; the ‘civil and military officials: the. the Ulema; Qnidehs, Sheikhs, Notables ‘and’ Inbibitants of the Sudan, on the occasion of your first visit to this country in your capacity ‘as thie Official Representative of His. Majesty King Edward--Vil, desire to "express to you jx ours warm appreciation of your presence amongst us. Yourdistinguishied predecessor; the Right Honourable the Earl of Cromer, on the occasion of his last visit to the Sudan, gave a brief outline‘ of the general and local adminis- | trative policy adopted in this. country, adding. that: the.execution of this programme in no |" to carry it out, and, deeply ne and all of us deplore the loss: we have ‘siistained by the withdrawal of his guiding hand, we fully realise the truth “of his words .and we. see, in your ‘appointment as his successor, the determina- tion of the joint st le Soudan—His way depended upon the rio fwho,had Majesty the’ King andy Highness the Khedive —to continue the j@gt and equitable system of goveriment, which has: been. established under their duspices? in this. country, ,jhere- by true advancéient and. progress is being secured to its inhabitants. We trust that the changes you may notice since you last visited this country, just seven years ego, in company with Lord Cromef, | will sufficiently indicaté to you the measure -of advancement and progress which has been made in the.work of introdu- cing: administration and reforms into the} 4 Sudan ; and we are’ confident that the know- ledge and information which you will acquire\ a daring your present tour, will enable you to tadviée the British and Egyptian. authorities on the best and surest means, -by which further development may be attained.

On behalf of the officials and inhabitants of this town, we desire to. offer you a warm welcome to Khartoum, and we cordially wish you health and strength. to serve your King and Country and to aid usin developing for the Sudan that good government in the main- tenance of which Great Britain, and Egypt are equally interested.
In reply, Sir Eldon Gorst Gia.
Tae ona and Gentlemen,

I -beg Sto thank you most warmly for your hearty welcome and for the address you have been good enough to, present to me. I have taken the first possible, opportunity: after my appointmént as His Majesty’s Representative in this country -to visit/the Sudan, in order that I may see with my owneyes the . progress which has béen ‘éfiedted since my last visit, seven years ego; to which the Sirdar has been good enough: to refer. I also hope to learn what are the wants and wishesof theinhabitants tor the immediate future, so that I may be’ in a position to carry out the mission which"has “| been entrusted to- me by His Majesty: King Edward VII. and His Majesty’s Govern- ment., It seems almost; unnecessary’ to state that there will be nochange of any kind in the policy which was laid down by Lord Cromer‘ and: approved by the Government of His High- ness‘the Khedive, and which, -as carried out by your Excellency and by all the civiland militaty officials, both “Britishy and: Egyptian, under your ‘orders; has already effected so wonderful a trgnstormation. So long as we all .| of us conse to collaborate heartily ‘and loyally for the welfare and prosperity of the Sudan, !, for one, have no fear that the progréss which has been attained in the past will not continue in the futare, dud so tar as lam personally concerned, 1) can promise yon that you will always find.mé just as ready as- Lord Cromer to help andAdvise you in your work,’ and to support you®in all your. difficulties ”
We will reserve our comments on the speech until to-morrow’s issue.

The Cairo newspapers comment on the fact that a telegram was despatched to the Ministry of the Interior from Khartoum on New Years’ Day and communicated officially to the Press announcing that Sir Eldon Gorst landed a fish weighing 52 lbs from the: Nile at that town on the Ist inst., after a struggle of | one and three quarters hours, and yet com- | plete silence is maintained as to Sir Eldon’s n| speech there, which has been commented on -, | by the London Press
The Nationalist Press make use of the incident in their ;wonted fashion. For example “Al'Ahram” remarks :—

“When he reached Khartoum Sir E. Gerst delivered a political speech which was trans- mitted to:England but whose,porport; was not |. . communicated. to the Egyptian press by Reuter’s Agency: which atinually receives out ofthe money of the. fellaheen L:B 2,000.”

“Thus the. Englishwho pay not a penny to the Sudan exchequer were considered as more entitled to know the mature of this. speech chan. Egyptians who. psy.,the expensea.of the "Sudan and s pply, theif: sons.for its service.”
“What will the Occupationists say to, this sort of treatment ?”
“Can it bes described. as ‘anything iotlee a contempt for the farites nation ?”

“For the tak is ; that the, Bieaian ‘aan demands its usurped. rights and the smallest part of these rights is to restoresuthority to the 3 natives. But the largest. .part-consists in -giving, her all her rights, respecting her-as a nation end not despising her to such.an extent | as to conceal the purport of important political speeches deliyeredon the futureof the country.”
“ We are bound to say-that. though we have praised Sir E. Gorst for some aspects of his policy we are not pleased with his last action.”

“Had Sir E.Gorst been desiring to act in harmony with us he.would baye communicated his speech to H. H. the Khediya and. to our | Ministers.and.then to the Egyptian;Press so as tolet the public know. it. But he acted contrary to that policy, so we find ourselves. obliged on behalf of the whole. nation to, protest.”

div.head: “HUNGRY SEAMEN IN “RED SEA”
div.p: The story of an unfortunate voyage from Port Said to the Persian Gulf is reported in the latest London papers, While the 8, 8.“Savona” was on the way from Savona to Port Said there was a shortage of potatoes and flour, and when ‘the crew left Port Said on: Sept. 14th complaint was made to the steward that they | were not getting the food they were entitled to. The ship remained in the Persian Gulf about eight'weeks, during which timé'the food was bad, and the crew did not get's proper | ‘| supply of anything: ‘When the captain was apporached he replied that he could not give them their proper allowance, as he only took provisions for six weeks.
During the time the ship was in the Red Sea each man had two quarts of water allowed him in twenty four hours instead of five quarts. The temperature at that particular time was 134deg.

On Friday week at the Thames Police Court the magistrate said the captain was aolely res- ponsible for what occurred. In the-case’of the seaman Hill there would be a fine of £10 and £15 15s. costs; in the second case £1 1s, would be allowedas compensation, together with £2 2s. costa, while six seamen would cach receive £1 1s. by: way of compensation, and in addition ‘would each be awarded 15s. costs.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIM.
div.p: CHRISTMAS DAY.
(From ovr own CoRRESPONDENT). : Saaktim,-Boxing Day.

Chritmasday. was recognised as a holiday here by..all; the-Goverament:Departments. In tae morning: most» of -the: British: .representa- tives.of business firms seeeiwed complimentary visits from the leading: Native sand::dndiau merchants and several of the Egyptian officials of the Government: “Althotgh unfortunately unable to be spresentiibimself, Miralai 0/4: Hawker Bey invited the principal British resi- dents to. dinner at the.Mudirieh. ‘He yas,’ however, most’ efficiently represented by “Mr. Morgan, Civil Judge, and Bimbashi ©. H. Tindall-Lueas.-Considering-the-very limited resources atstheir disposal, the table was most | ‘ingenionsly and tastefully. degarated. by; hands | which displayed, artistic. tasteof no mean.order, and the,pleasing,,efiact, produced ..was,greatly appreciated by all. Twa lgrge blacks..ofjice placed in the centre of the festive board help- ed to keep the temperature of the room beauti- fullycool,and far from creating afrost, materially helped, with the assistange of excellent sub- titutes for snow and holly herries, to lend a very homelike and wintry appearance. to the scene. Fifteen sat down to table and did ample justice to an excellegt menu. The reluctance of the party to disperse was ample testimony that the evening was ost thorougly. enjoyed by everyone.
Miralai .C.J.. Hawker. Bey retarned early this morning, having trecked by, camel from ‘Kurora, His return, was«considerably delayed by: frequent.heavy rains,

A. small:tennis-Tournament’ took place’ on the Sporting: Club court: this. afternoon. Six couples took part, and time being limited, sets were restricted to’ the- best‘of five-games ; each pair playing every other pair-one set. The‘ winners- were: Bimbashi ‘Tindall-Lucas and-'T.E Fyres,

The 8.8. ‘‘Mariont’” ofthe, Khedivial mail Line left to-day for Djeddah with nearly, 900 pilgrims. The declaration of cholera in Mecca and Medina inno: way damps: ‘their-ardour, in fact it seems:to.stimulate it, for to die in the Holy City is-to them almost .am-ambition; and ' | @ certain. means ‘oft-attaining’ the Paradise their religious:teacking: promises them. December 27.

All Suakim must have.turned out to witness the sports today, ‘which were held on the polo groond at Fort Foulah. .The . programme was most varied and lengthy, ,consisting of no less than 19 events. There was. a diversity o | | races fon ther hoya | attending, the Government School, as well asa gymnastic exercise compe- tition. Most of. the other events were open to the men of the 7th,-and' Railway-Battalions, Police, and Slavery Departments; and included asack-race, a marching: order race;-police race (to run'50. yards and-bring in prisoner hand- cuffed) and bootrace In the latter thecompe- titors were blindfold; -they had to find a pair of boots laced. It wasa most amusing eveot. The wrestling on mules was splendid and the men took a lot of moving ; their arms and legs seemed to cling. to:their animals like the ten “| tacles of an octopus. The,wrestling on camels was not quite such asuccess. The tugs of war created immense excitement, especially when the 7th and Railway Battalions teams came together. The 7th A. team won by 2 pulls to 1. -| All three pulls were splendidly contested. Much, interest was created when teams from t.| Svakim and the 8.8. “Nidderdale” were’pitted T. | against.each other ; .th@ result being a win for the former. after: a. very,steady pull. The horse race. was. good,. bath; fitst.and second places were easily secured by Major C.J. Hawkers horses ridden by Bimbashi.Forth.and himself respectively.

The camel race. was /keenly contested for moat of.the distance, but the. eventual. winner forged a,head at the end. and, won easily. Tea and refreshments were.liberally dispensed on the ground. The prizes, were distributed by the Governor. The Committee consisting of El Miralai C. J. Hawker Bey, Bimbasbi, R.E.M. Rossel, Bimbashi C.H. Tindall Lucas, Mr. G. Akers-Douglas, and several officera of the Battalion, by ‘their energy afd forethought “ensured the success of the meeting.

div.head: A UNWERATY OF AFRICA.
div.p: The French.. Miniater-off Public: Instruction has direoted.a committee: to draft:a bill: for the Creation of a “University of.Africa” in Algeria. Commenting..on this. announcement in the Paris “Temps” a. correspondent: writes:to the ‘Manchester . Guardian” : ‘I: avell. remember being) strack when I was in Algeria: same years ago by the sight of posters in: the-verna- cular advocating rival candidatures for election "| to the Chamber of Depation which. brought home'to the’mind ‘of an Englishman the nuvel fact that a dependency inhabited almost "| entirely, by aborigines was given raptasantation in, the Parliament of the stepmother,conntry. The French have .shown, more.courage in dealing with the education problem than we ' in Egypt, for the higher schools employ the native tongue, and in the new University will probably devote themselves to the much- neglected study of African dialects. It is extraordinary “how little we, with our yast empire over Oriental and African, subjects, do to encourage these studies, As,a recent depn- tation to Mr. Morley pointed out, we, with millions of Oriental sabjecta «make: far -leas provision for the ascientifie-study-of Oriental languages than-the Germans; who have~practi- cally no such subjects at all.”

div.head: EGYPTIAN pOLITios
div.p: THE, FICTION OF PARTIES

Our parties are; evidently. trying, says the Cairo Coptic organ ‘Al Watan,” to come to a reognised form, but the very, efforts made in thie-way’ are battering these! parties out of}. bape-end leaving the uninitiated stranger in a-wildenness of uncertainty on.the subject. We chave always been.told that thete.isan Extreme |’ Nationalist,.party in Egypt. led hy .Mustafa Pasha Kamel .and..a.Modemte Nationalist leagne headed by Sheikh Ali. Youssef. Now | that the two paxties. have; sliown. themselves and exponnded their. principles -in. two, public meetings it is almost impossible to recognise from the addresses of the respective leaders which is which _ At times.you find the leader of the Extremists preaching moderation” while the head of the Moderates favours extreme megsures, and.vice yersa. Yet the substance ofthe inaugural addresses made by the,two rival chiefs before their respective followers and supporters was one and the’ same thing 'They,both want England to_ to grant, her— presumably before leaving—a constitution, every otber subject mentioned in the twomeetings herein referred to was only secondary and of comparatively little im- portance. ‘Whether the Pashas and Beys and Sheikhs and Effendis who. assisied-at those two meetings arestill in the belief that’ they formed two separate and distinct parties atter reading the two adresses it is hard to tell.. But that both parties are one in Mobamedan brotherhood and; in hating the alien race of rulers is # fact which can never be controverted or denied.

The meeting of the Extreme party-at the office of “Al-Lewe.” was, it appears, mere nume- nsly, attended than the rival meeting. of the y, founded and headed by.the owner of “Al- Moayad.” But quality evidently, made up for |" .quantity in,the latter meeting, for it comprised aconsiderable number of titled somebodies, including a Khedivial Prince who is the direct grand-sonof the greatf under of ourruling house and a brother-in-law to our present Khedive. ‘This Prinee did not take an active part in the meeting, but to.some observers his presence’ was hardly in.conformity with ‘the rule of | princes who are considered above the wrangles of political parties. It-was also‘ observed that this Prince assisted at a meeting the first aim of which was to protest against the British |. occupation, whereas he owes everything in his possession now to ‘that occupation and to its agents. In this, we think, he was at one with the whole assembly, for it is to the occupation alone that we owe the liberty to claim a change in our rulers and our laws: We shall revert to the subject of these parties in the near future.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Marshal. Riza Pasha, Traffic’ Manager of the Hedjaa Railway, has telegraphed to the High Commission,particulars of the journey of the. Sacred Caravan. The. journey: from’ Damascus ‘to El-Bedai-which formerly took 25 days was effected in four days The Caravan’s departure, from El-Bedai was attended with much pomp and solemnity and before the train started prayers were offered up for H.I.M the Sultan |’ in presence of the Director-General of the rail- wey works and ofa.great number of pilgrims amongst whom were the brother of the” Shah Persia and his mother.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From oR. own CoRRESPONDENT.)
London, December'27th.
Major H.M. Orr, D.S0., ‘Yorkshire Regi- ment, commanding the Depot companies, Richmond, has just taken hisretired pay, having been caught up by the age rulgs.
Captain John H. Davidson, D.S0., King’s Royal Rifle Corps, n-brought in on fthe |: establishment by the sec@nding of Major H. R. Blore, whilst holding-a ‘staff billet.
Lieutenant P. W. Maynard, Royal Irish Ri- fles, has. been formally séconded for service with the Egyptian Army.
The men of the Beyptian drafts are now on farlough prior to embarkation on the 16th prox

The It.is understgod that the army estimates for" the coming’ year are in the process of formula; { tion. Thiscis-abit earlier than-usual, but it ig ) being done in order that the advive on the spot ’ of General the Honourable Sir N: GQ. Lyttle- ton @ C.B., Chief of the Staff, may.be avail- able before he goes to Ireland aext month. to | 4 succeed Lord @renfell as Commander in Chief. From what can. be gathered concerning the es- timates, not a single penny will be economised afterall Mr. Haldane’s‘‘olearthinking”although | * he has‘ reduced: the standing army by nearly 20,000 to make it “more effective”. Verb. sap.
From the Ist January; tecruits enlisted for the Foot Guards are to be sent after final. ap- proval, direct to the Guards Depot, Caterham, instead of to the headquarters of the regiment in Longon.
Service with the Egyptian Army seems to be J very popular. There is now a long waiting list of candidates for service with the Khedivial troops.

Captain Somerset A. G@ Calthorpe, M.V.0., from’the commandof the firstclass “Roxburgh,” First “Crujsef Squadron, attached to the Channel Fleet, ha been appointed to the|* command of the first class battleship Hindu- stan, of the Ghannel Fleet squadron. £ i Calthorpe, who is a member of an t “family, of which Lord Calthorpe, is the Senior representative, has served afloat fur thirty two.years, and -he-has goue through tw pediticns the Brass River Expedifi (mentioned in despatches, medal th ole and the expedition against, Mburruk, a recalei- trant Arab chief, who in 1895 set British law at/defiance. and who had to be- taught the “inevitable lesson. His eervices were recognised by special promotion to the rank of comman- | * der. Captain Calthorpe is well known on the Mediterranean station. °

The statement that a North Pacific Squa; | ‘ dron;was to be restablishedas asetoff tothe des- | - patch of-the f.S. Pacific Fleet to the Far Bast has been officially contradicted. All the same that squadron will be revived in the falness_ of time.

Mr. Haldane’s edict has gone forth, and twenty three battalions of Militia several « which patriotically: volunteered for i South Africa and did good service there, are |‘ to be disbanded in order to make the army and its second’ line more effective. Nearly 20,000 regulars have been passed into the | § limbo.of the reserve to thake".the army more effective, and nom somé -9,000-militiawen are tobe disposed ‘of tavefder. to.raake that branch | § ot the service more. effective, The battalions to be destroyed -are the 4th Battalions Royal Lancaster Regiment, Norfolk Regiment, Lin- coln Regiment, Suffolk Regiment, Somerset- shire Light Infantry, Yorkshire Regiment, y Cheshire- Regiment, Royal Welsh Fusiliers, South Wales Borderers, Gloucester Regiment, Border Regiment, Essex Regiment, and Shrop- shire Light Infantry; the 3rd Battalions Devonshire Regiment,. Royal Irish Regiment, Oxfordshire: Light Infantry, and Connanght Rangers, and the 5th Battalions RayAl Innis- killing Fusiliers, and Royal Irish Fusiliers_and the 6th Battalions Royal Irish Rifles and Rifle Brigade andthe 8th and 9th. Battalions Rifle Brigade—in all, fifteen English and eight Irish battalions. Not a single Scottish battalion ‘has tegn,earmarked for destraction, thanks to the Scottish element in the Government. -Of the remaining-battalions, 74 are to be made reserve battalions to’ 69 line battalions and 27 will be made extra réserve battalions under some new fangled name.. Just as if the time honoured term, ‘Militia,”. which the old Constitational Foree. .haa:-borne for over.six centari good'endugh. Many an officer gerving in will read with tegret of the impending dissolu- tion-of the battalion in which he first learned soldiering

div.head: THE EDITOR REGRETS
div.p: “When I was city editér of. ginia City Enterprise,’” r arked Mark ‘Twain at a dinner in New York, ‘‘a fine turkey. was one. day left at the office.
“Torkeys were rare in that high altitude, and we all hankered after this bird. The pro- prigtor, though, claimed it for his own. He took it home and had it cooked for dinner.
"The next day, as he was expatiating on the turkey’s richness and tendarness, a letter was handed to him, He opened it and read :—
“ Mr. Editor :—
"Sir—Yesterday I sent you a turkey which has been: the-cause of much dispute among us. To settle a bet, will you kindly ask your agricultural editor to state in_ to- morrow’s issue what it died of.’”

div.head: FOOTBALL AT PORT-SAID.
div.p: Port Said International Club. played theit third match with the Government,Sehaol on Saturday-.afternoon-on. the.clab.ground—before a fair crowd of spectators: ‘The game at the outset was evenly contested anda fine break through by the Port Said forwards was unsuj ceseful.. The-ball was soon returned’ to mi field and neither side could break through the defence. a long kick-by Ashton found touch well down the field, after which Port Said: pressed. P. Velleand Munk putin some fine shots’ which the native goal’ keeper saved well. From'a corner kick King put the ball in thd} 2 mouth of the goal and Munk did the needful by finding.the net. From the kick off. Port Said, attacked ‘again, HoweandP. Vella playing in grand combination gave the native goal keeper a,warm.time but.he proved equal to, the occasion and saved well time after time. Athalftime Port Said were. leading by one goal. In the opening-etages-of the second half play was very exciting and, after a short spell of defensive work, the natives got-dway and’ ‘pressed hard. A. Vella who was. playing, for! the natives equalized. matters.amid greatcheers. After the kick’off Port Said pressed and had things very much'their own way. Field and P. Vella found the net. in quick succession and || a shortly.atter the latter,.player scored, his ge- | cond Port Said were-still pressing when time | ” was called. ‘Rinal soore Port Said\Club 4 goals' School 1.

div.head: THE LIVER AND STOMACH.
div.p: FACTS YOU.OUGHT TO KNOW.

The liver and. stomach work harmoniously together, to chitnge thefood we_eat, into blood, bone, and tissue. The stomach supplies the gastric juice which digests the albuminous part‘of our food; and the bile from the liver} 3 completes the process'of digestion by acting on the oils andifats, The digested food. is then ready for conversion into pure, rich blood. When, however, ‘the stomach and liver are ont of order, there is not-ehough] y gastric juice and bile formed. to,completely digest the food and form new blood, and the undigested food, wearies and irritates the delicate mechanism, and clogs the bowels. NOTICE TO TOURISTS.

We bas to inform all Ladies and Gentlemen Tourists that after having taken in serious consideration’ the latest \eomments on the behaviour of Dragomans, we have formed the above Society for the « ‘eafoty: and satisfaction of our patrons.

Our Society is composed of the best‘known respectable Dragomans, Guides and Couriers. well acquainted with the ‘business, the neces- sary languages, the ways, the Kistory of ruinet® monuments, not only, of Egypt but as well of Holy Land, Greece; Turkey and Europe. div.p: CONTRATS
Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchand. 6h. p.m.
REMARQUES
COTON-Nouvelle recolte: Demandee, mais addaires restreintes, faute de vendeurs. Cours tres fermes.

Recolte nxxmelle: Eu commerve a achere dans l'aores-midi et cela a contribue a raffermir les cours. En cloture nous acons au une legere reaction, mais quand meme nous resions en benefice de 7/82 sur la coture de 1 heure.
Dans la matinee prix plus haus pour mars talarie 12 3.32 a -/-; plus bas pour mars 12 1/16 a -/-. Dans l'apres-midi prix plus haus pour mars 12 3 8 a -/-; plus has pour mars 12 7/32 a -/-.
